elements.content: Smart materials are highly desirable over the recent decade due to the growing demand of complicated nature. Stable stimuli-responsive smart materials exhibit widespread potential for applications in smart windows, sensors, separators, chemical valves, and release platforms but are rare. Despite being good candidates, viologen-based multifunctional smart materials are still a challenging task for chemists. To obtain such materials, the judicious strategy is to introduce polynuclear metal–carboxylate clusters as electron donors into a stable framework to increase chromic sensitivity. Toward this endeavor, we have synthesized a novel viologen-based polymer with a unique Anderson-like metal–carboxylate cluster, [Zn7(bpybc)3(o-BDC)6]·2NO3·6H2O (bpybc = 1,1′-bis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium, o-BDC = o-benzenedicarboylic acid) (1), which is a particular 7-fold interpenetrated framework with a 3D pcu network in which bpybc ligand as the linker and Zn7O30C12 as the second building unit (Zn7 SBU) were used as 6-connected nodes. More importantly, it shows excellent chromic behavior in response to multiple external stimuli especially soft X-ray and UV dual light, temperature, electricity, and organic amines, which stand out in the viologen-based polymers. Interestingly, the coloration process of 1 from “core” to “edge” is observed upon heating at the appropriate temperature, which has not yet been found in other reported thermochromic materials. Of particular interest for 1 is the couple of quaternary stimuli-sensitive abilities because it simultaneously meets the following conditions: (i) the capability of withstanding high light, higher temperature, extreme pH, and other harsh conditions; and (ii) the high sensitivity to external stimuli keeping away from photodegradation, thermal relaxation, side reactions, and so on. To be noted, 1 has high thermal stability and chemical stability, which are excellent advantages as smart materials. To further develop possible practical utilization, 1 has been doped into the polymer matrixes to construct a hybrid film, which not only keeps the response to external stimuli but also significantly improves the repeatability of the photochromic process, indicating that a new smart device with multi-stimuli-responsive functions will emerge successively in the future.

elements.content: Driven by the need to develop intelligent technology, stimuli-sensitive materials have received tremendous scientific attention in various applications such as mimicking of photosynthetic solar energy conversion, molecular shuttles, recyclable catalysis, sensing, coating, separation, nanotechnology, biology, tissue engineering, energy harvesting, secret writing, smart window, rewritable copy paper, controlled drug delivery vehicle, and so forth. Of various stimuli-sensitive materials, crystalline chromic materials such as diarylethenes, benzo­[b]­phosphole, spiropyran, spirooxazine, viologens, and azobenzene compounds with reversible color changes have attracted a great deal of interest, because of their highly designable and controllable geometric structures, the convenient and efficient chromic behavior, and the readable corresponding signals with regenerated and reused characters in response to external chemical or physical stimuli. Among various crystalline chromic materials, viologens with electron-deficient nature, whose color can be adjusted via chemical, electrical, or optical stimuli, are well-known for their great potentials in smart technologic applications. With the assistance of electron-rich species, they can undergo a two-step redox process and exhibit three different states (neutral V0, radical cation V•+, dication V2+) via the electron transfer from electron-donating inorganic ions or organic ligands to electron-deficient viologen components of frameworks. These three different states own disparate electronic dissociation, which lead to different electronic absorption bands, accompanied by the visible color change. On the basis of the character, viologen materials can directly display a revisible and visible color change in response to the external stimuli such as pH, heat, light irradiation, electric potential, solvent, and organic amines. Unfortunately, the most known viologen-based chromic materials only respond to monostimulus. Actually, the natural stimuli are multiple and generally include light, electricity, heat, and chemical. Thus, the known viologen-based materials have limited application. Another important issue in the field is how to obtain a viologen material with a fast responsibility and high stability because reported viologen materials usually show a slow responsive rate (photochromism time usually more than 10 min under light irradiation and the fading of color from several hours to months; thermochromism time generally more than 1 h and the fading time taking much longer) and poor stability (the coloration usually unstable). Development of a fast and stable multistimuli responsive viologen-based hybrid remains a tough task to meet with practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Driven by the need to develop intelligent technology, stimuli-sensitive materials have received tremendous scientific attention in various applications such as mimicking of photosynthetic solar energy conversion, molecular shuttles, recyclable catalysis, sensing, coating, separation, nanotechnology, biology, tissue engineering, energy harvesting, secret writing, smart window, rewritable copy paper, controlled drug delivery vehicle, and so forth. Of various stimuli-sensitive materials, crystalline chromic materials such as diarylethenes, benzo[b]phosphole, spiropyran, spirooxazine, viologens, and azobenzene compounds with reversible color changes have attracted a great deal of interest, because of their highly designable and controllable geometric structures, the convenient and efficient chromic behavior, and the readable corresponding signals with regenerated and reused characters in response to external chemical or physical stimuli. Among various crystalline chromic materials, viologens with electron-deficient nature, whose color can be adjusted via chemical, electrical, or optical stimuli, are well-known for their great potentials in smart technologic applications. With the assistance of electron-rich species, they can undergo a two-step redox process and exhibit three different states (neutral V0, radical cation V⋅+, dication V2+) via the electron transfer from electron-donating inorganic ions or organic ligands to electron-deficient viologen components of frameworks. These three different states own disparate electronic dissociation, which lead to different electronic absorption bands, accompanied by the visible color change. On the basis of the character, viologen materials can directly display a revisible and visible color change in response to the external stimuli such as pH, heat, light irradiation, electric potential, solvent, and organic amines. Unfortunately, the most known viologen-based chromic materials only respond to monostimulus. Actually, the natural stimuli are multiple and generally include light, electricity, heat, and chemical. Thus, the known viologen-based materials have limited application. Another important issue in the field is how to obtain a viologen material with a fast responsibility and high stability because reported viologen materials usually show a slow responsive rate (photochromism time usually more than 10 min under light irradiation and the fading of color from several hours to months; thermochromism time generally more than 1 h and the fading time taking much longer) and poor stability (the coloration usually unstable). Development of a fast and stable multistimuli responsive viologen-based hybrid remains a tough task to meet with practical applications.

elements.content: To develop stable and fast multi-stimuli-responsive materials, the judicious strategy is to incorporate the viologen derivatives into the excellent electron donors such as metal–carboxylate and polyoxometalate clusters and assemble the interpenetrating structural motif for stabilizing the reduced radicals and creating multibridges for electron transfers. Both polyoxometalate and metal–carboxylate clusters have inherent rich-electron groups, good redox activity, photoactivity, and excellent stability, which is beneficial to transfer electron to viologen to reach chromic properties. The metal–viologen materials constructed by polyoxometalate clusters such as Keggin or Anderson-type clusters as electron donors generally have the dark color, and thus their color change cannot be easily detected by the naked eye. While metal–viologen materials constructed by metal–carboxylate clusters usually possess the obvious color change, the reasons are as follows: (i) almost no electronic absorption bands are observed in the visible region before exposure to the external stimuli; and (ii) many electron-transfer pathways are good at the colored free radicals generated under different stimuli. When viologens are dispersed in the aprotic metal–organic framework, generated viologen radical cations can be stabilized by the surrounding solid matrix due to restriction of thermal back electron transfer and air oxidation. To pursue a stable and fast multi-stimuli-responsive chromic material, d10 Zn ion and o-benzenedicarboylic acid (o-H2BDC) are chosen to construct the electron-rich zinc–oxide clusters (ZnO clusters), which are favorable for increasing the sensitivity to external stimuli, and the flexible viologen ligand (1,1′-bis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium, bpybc) is chosen as an electron acceptor to interact with electron-rich ZnO clusters. As expected, a 7-fold interpenetrated Anderson-like cluster-based Zn­(II) MOF, [Zn7(bpybc)3(o-BDC)6]·2NO3·6H2O (1), can exhibit a stable and fast response to various external stimuli, especially soft X-ray, UV-light, heat, electricity, and some organic amines, mainly due to that the abundant O atoms in the Anderson-like clusters are favorable for forming much more electron transfer pathways and further improving the possibility for the effective electron transfer under the external stimuli. To be noted, sample 1 has high thermal stability and chemical stability, which are excellent advantages as smart materials for far-reaching application. Thus, to further develop the utilization value, sample 1 has been doped into the polymer matrixes to construct a new poly­(methyl methacrylate)-supported (PMMA) hybrid film, which not only keeps the response to external stimuli but also significantly improves the repeatability of the photochromic process.

elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared by a solvothermal reaction of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, o-benzenedicarboylic acid (o-H2BDC), and 1,1′-bis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium dichloride (H2bpybcCl2) in a mixture solvents of dimethylformamide (DMF), ethanol (EtOH), and water. The ligand H2bpybcCl2 was synthesized according to previously reported literature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis and Characterization

Compound 1 was prepared by a solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, o-benzenedicarboylic acid (o-H2BDC), and 1,1'-bis(4-carboxyphenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium dichloride (H2bpybcCl2) in a mixture solvents of dimethylformamide (DMF), ethanol (EtOH), and water. The ligand H2bpybcCl2 was synthesized according to previously reported literature.

elements.content: Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.149 g, 0.5 mmol), o-H2BDC (0.035 g, 0.2 mmol), and H2bpybcCl2 (0.099 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (2 mL), EtOH (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL). The pH value was adjusted to 7 with NaOH solution. The solution was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was then heated at 90 °C for 7 days and then slowly cooled to room temperature at 5 °C/min. After being filtered off and dried at room temperature, 1 was obtained as a yellow block crystal in 40% yield based on H2BpybcCl2. Anal. Calcd for C126H118N7O56Zn7 (1): C, 49.07; H, 3.86; N, 3.18. Found: C, 48.96; H, 3.83; N, 3.19. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3442 (s), 3117 (w), 2346 (w), 2031 (w), 1600 (s), 1381 (s), 1121 (s), 812 (w), 759 (m), 668 (w), 615 (m), 551 (w), 471 (w).

Synthesis of 1 

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.149 g, 0.5 mmol), o-H2BDC (0.035 g, 0.2 mmol), and H2bpybcCl2 (0.099 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (2 mL), EtOH (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL). The pH value was adjusted to 7 with NaOH solution. The solution was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was then heated at 90 °C for 7 days and then slowly cooled to room temperature at 5 °C/min. After being filtered off and dried at room temperature, 1 was obtained as a yellow block crystal in 40% yield based on H2BpybcCl2. Anal. Calcd for C126H118N7O56Zn7 (1): C, 49.07; H, 3.86; N, 3.18. Found: C, 48.96; H, 3.83; N, 3.19. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3442 (s), 3117 (w), 2346 (w), 2031 (w), 1600 (s), 1381 (s), 1121 (s), 812 (w), 759 (m), 668 (w), 615 (m), 551 (w), 471 (w).

elements.content: The solid-state UV–vis diffuse-reflectance spectrum was determined on a TU-1901 spectrophotometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex II X-ray diffractometer. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis data were carried out on a SETARAM LABSYS equipment. Elemental analyses were recorded on a vario EL-II analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed on a Nicolet 5DX spectrometer. Photochromic properties were determined upon ultraviolet light irradiation (22.4 mw/cm2). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical analyzer (Shanghai). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were performed using a Bruker EMX spectrometer.

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data were performed on an Agilent Technologies Gemini EOS diffractometer at 293(2) K with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Pertinent crystallographic data and structural results for 1 and 1P are summarized in .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies show that compound 1 has an Anderson-like Zn7 cluster-based 7-fold interpenetrated 3D structure. It crystallizes in trigonal space group R3̅, and there are two crystallographically independent Zn ions, one-half bpybc ligand, one o-BDC2– ligand, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit (a). Zn ions display two types of coordination environments. Zn(1) shows a slightly distorted tetrahedron coordination sphere, coordinated by four monodentate carboxyl oxygen atom from one bpybc ligand and three different o-BDC2– ligands (a). Zn(2) ion in a special position lies on a 3-fold axis with a site occupancy of 1/6, coordinated by six monodentate carboxylate oxygens from o-BDC2– ligands, in which the axial positions are occupied by two carboxyl oxygen atoms with a O–Zn–O angle of 180°, and the equatorial plane is occupied by four oxygen atoms with the O–Zn–O angle in the range of 88.95(8)–91.05(8)°, indicating a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in b, Zn(2) as a center is surrounded by six adjacent Zn(1) ions, which is connected through six o-BDC2– ligands with μ2-η1:η1 bidentate mode, resulting in an inorganic core of Zn7O30C12 second building unit (Zn7 SBU) (Figure S1). The Zn7 SBU can be described as Anderson-like cluster, which is constructed by six ZnO4 tetrahedra moieties arranged in a cyclic manner (Zn6(CO2)6 ring) through Zn–(μ2-η1:η1 OCO)–Zn bridges connected to the central ZnO6 octahedron (b). Each Anderson-like Zn7 SBU is bridged by six bpybc ligands, and each bpybc ligand is linked by two Zn7 SBUs (c), thus forming a pcu topological framework with quadrilateral rings (Figure S2). The quadrilateral rings are so large that seven identical but independent sets of networks interpenetrate to give a 7-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (d and e). Despite the 7-fold interpenetration, it is still a porous framework with channels containing guest molecules, whose potential void spaces have been estimated to 20.6% per unit volume by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. To be noted, the porous framework is positively charged, which is balanced by nitrates. The presence of NO3  anion can be confirmed by FT-IR spectra and ion chromatography (Figures S3–S5). After exposure to UV light or X-rays, there are obvious bond-length changes in the crystal structure. In detail, Zn–O distances and most other band distances only increased with a small variation of <0.005 Å, similar to previous reports. C(11)–C­(11f) linking of two pyridinium rings in the viologen ligand was obviously increased with the distance value from 1.482 Å in the colorless form to 1.496 Å in the blue form. Also, N+–C distances (N(1)–C(8)) were also obviously elongated 0.009 Å after light irradiation, which further proves that the pyridinium nitrogen was reduced to neutral.

Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies show that compound 1 has an Anderson-like Zn7 cluster-based 7-fold interpenetrated 3D structure. It crystallizes in trigonal space group R3̅, and there are two crystallographically independent Zn ions, one-half bpybc ligand, one o-BDC2- ligand, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit (a). Zn ions display two types of coordination environments. Zn(1) shows a slightly distorted tetrahedron coordination sphere, coordinated by four monodentate carboxyl oxygen atom from one bpybc ligand and three different o-BDC2- ligands (a). Zn(2) ion in a special position lies on a 3-fold axis with a site occupancy of 1/6, coordinated by six monodentate carboxylate oxygens from o-BDC2- ligands, in which the axial positions are occupied by two carboxyl oxygen atoms with a O-Zn-O angle of 180°, and the equatorial plane is occupied by four oxygen atoms with the O-Zn-O angle in the range of 88.95(8)-91.05(8)°, indicating a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. As shown in b, Zn(2) as a center is surrounded by six adjacent Zn(1) ions, which is connected through six o-BDC2- ligands with μ2-η1:η1 bidentate mode, resulting in an inorganic core of Zn7O30C12 second building unit (Zn7 SBU) (Figure S1). The Zn7 SBU can be described as Anderson-like cluster, which is constructed by six ZnO4 tetrahedra moieties arranged in a cyclic manner (Zn6(CO2)6 ring) through Zn-(μ2-η1:η1 OCO)-Zn bridges connected to the central ZnO6 octahedron (b). Each Anderson-like Zn7 SBU is bridged by six bpybc ligands, and each bpybc ligand is linked by two Zn7 SBUs (c), thus forming a pcu topological framework with quadrilateral rings (Figure S2). The quadrilateral rings are so large that seven identical but independent sets of networks interpenetrate to give a 7-fold interpenetrated 3D framework (d and e). Despite the 7-fold interpenetration, it is still a porous framework with channels containing guest molecules, whose potential void spaces have been estimated to 20.6% per unit volume by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. To be noted, the porous framework is positively charged, which is balanced by nitrates. The presence of NO3  anion can be confirmed by FT-IR spectra and ion chromatography (Figures S3-S5). After exposure to UV light or X-rays, there are obvious bond-length changes in the crystal structure. C(11)-C(11f) linking of two pyridinium rings in the viologen ligand was obviously increased with the distance value from 1.482 Å in the colorless form to 1.496 Å in the blue form. elements.content: Generally, viologen-based materials are photoactive and usually undergo a visible color change via electron transfer (ET) upon UV light irradiation. Such a phenomenon has been also observed in the as-synthesized yellow sample 1, which can undergo a rapid visible photochromic transformation with exposure to ultraviolet light in air at room temperature. Upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp for about 1 min, 1 gradually turns from yellow to blue (1P), and no further color change was observed after continuous irradiation for 20 min. The blue crystals (1P) are stable in air and slowly decolored in dark at ambient temperature for more than 14 days. A fast back to orange color can be completed by heating at 120 °C for about 4 h. Such chromic and bleaching process is partially repeated for 10 cycles by alternate UV irradiation and heating treatment. This can be explained in that the removal of lattice water molecules by heating treatment enlarges the effective channel and makes oxygen molecules easy to diffuse into the framework to accelerate the oxidative quenching of viologen radicals. This kind of color change can be monitored by the solid-state diffuse reflectance spectrum (Figure S6) and EPR signal (Figure S7), which further indicate that the presence of lattice water molecules is related to the reversibility of photochromism. Besides efficient photochromism in response to UV light, more importantly, 1 shows a selective response to X-ray sources. X-ray is expected to be more effective for radical generation in the photochromic materials due to high energy. During single-crystal X-ray diffraction (an Agilent Technologies Gemini Eos single X-ray Cu Kα diffractometer λ = 1.5418 Å, powered at 1.2 kW), the color of crystalline sample 1 changes from yellow to dark blue for about 20 min (a). Meanwhile, a similar coloration phenomenon is also observed after Al Kα X-ray irradiation (Figure S8). The completed decoloration process also can be achieved by heating at 120 °C or putting in the dark at ambient temperature. When X-rays become harder, no noticeable color change is observed after illumination by a hard X-ray source (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) for 12 h, indicating that sample 1 is not responsive to hard X-ray irradiation but easily sensitive to UV light and soft X-rays at room temperature. The observed color change may originate from radical generation via electron transfer that mainly occurred at N1 and C11 atoms, because the N(1)–C(8) and C(11)–C­(11f) are elongated after light irradiation, which is similar to the viologen-based reversible photochromic materials. In this case, there are several possible pathways for electron transfer in the structure, which might be the reason why sample 1 can show a marked color change upon light irradiation of different frequencies. As we know, an appropriate short distance between the pyridinium N atom and the donor atom is necessary for electron transfer to generate radicals for X-ray- or UV-light-induced photochromic materials. The coloration of the reported X-ray- and UV-induced photochromic violegen-based materials is mainly caused by the electron transfer from donor O atom to pyridinium N atom, which is confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Figure S9). The X-ray-induced photochromic materials require a much higher threshold energy than UV-induced materials, which means that the electron-transfer pathway of X-ray-induced materials is longer than that of UV-induced materials. As reported, JU99, NTHU-9-MV, and blm-Co are all sensitive to X-rays, in which the shortest O···N distances between the electron-rich O atom and the electron-deficient N atom are 4.52, 4.83, and 4.29 Å, while in UV-induced compounds the distances are much shorter (such as JU98:3.45 Å, etc.). In 1, the shortest O···N distance between O4 and N1 atoms is 3.276 Å, and the distance of the offset π···π stacking between the pryridine ring and the benzene ring is 3.727 Å (Figure S10). These values favor the requirements for charge transfer under UV light. The dihedral angle between two pyridyl groups of the bipyridinium is 0°, which is favorable for stabilizing the charge delocalization degree and the free radicals. To be noted, compound 1 can be sensitive to not only UV light but also to soft X-ray, which might be due to that there are some longer O···N distances of 4.514, 4.582, 4.618, and 4.664 Å, quite close to the corresponding value (4.285 Å) of the reported X-ray- and UV-light-induced chromic compound [Zn2LBr4] (L = N,N′-dipropionate-4,4′-bipyridinium). Although no unequivocal criterion for the donor–acceptor distance of photochromic compounds has been established, according to previous studies and our cases (Table S2), the multipathway for electron transfer should play a key role in these viologen-based materials, which can undergo a visible color change under light of different frequencies. The sensitive detection of soft X-rays has been performed in crystalline solid through a visual color change, but it is well-known that the hybrid films are more convenient and efficient in the application as X-ray detectors. Such functional film materials can be constructed by doping sample 1 into the PMMA polymer (1@PMMA). As shown in b, 1@PMMA has also shown an efficient coloration process when it is irradiated by Cu Kα radiation. With increasing X-ray irradiation time, the color of 1@PMMA has become much deeper. Thus, 1@PMMA can be very conveniently and widely used in detecting soft X-rays.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromic Properties

Generally, viologen-based materials are photoactive and usually undergo a visible color change via electron transfer (ET) upon UV light irradiation. Such a phenomenon has been also observed in the as-synthesized yellow sample 1, which can undergo a rapid visible photochromic transformation with exposure to ultraviolet light in air at room temperature. Upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp for about 1 min, 1 gradually turns from yellow to blue (1P), and no further color change was observed after continuous irradiation for 20 min. The blue crystals (1P) are stable in air and slowly decolored in dark at ambient temperature for more than 14 days. A fast back to orange color can be completed by heating at 120 °C for about 4 h. Such chromic and bleaching process is partially repeated for 10 cycles by alternate UV irradiation and heating treatment. This can be explained in that the removal of lattice water molecules by heating treatment enlarges the effective channel and makes oxygen molecules easy to diffuse into the framework to accelerate the oxidative quenching of viologen radicals. This kind of color change can be monitored by the solid-state diffuse reflectance spectrum (Figure S6) and EPR signal (Figure S7), which further indicate that the presence of lattice water molecules is related to the reversibility of photochromism. Besides efficient photochromism in response to UV light, more importantly, 1 shows a selective response to X-ray sources. X-ray is expected to be more effective for radical generation in the photochromic materials due to high energy. During single-crystal X-ray diffraction (an Agilent Technologies Gemini Eos single X-ray Cu Kα diffractometer λ = 1.5418 Å, powered at 1.2 kW), the color of crystalline sample 1 changes from yellow to dark blue for about 20 min (a). Meanwhile, a similar coloration phenomenon is also observed after Al Kα X-ray irradiation (Figure S8). The completed decoloration process also can be achieved by heating at 120 °C or putting in the dark at ambient temperature. When X-rays become harder, no noticeable color change is observed after illumination by a hard X-ray source (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) for 12 h, indicating that sample 1 is not responsive to hard X-ray irradiation but easily sensitive to UV light and soft X-rays at room temperature. The observed color change may originate from radical generation via electron transfer that mainly occurred at N1 and C11 atoms, because the N(1)-C(8) and C(11)-C(11f) are elongated after light irradiation, which is similar to the viologen-based reversible photochromic materials. In this case, there are several possible pathways for electron transfer in the structure, which might be the reason why sample 1 can show a marked color change upon light irradiation of different frequencies. As we know, an appropriate short distance between the pyridinium N atom and the donor atom is necessary for electron transfer to generate radicals for X-ray- or UV-light-induced photochromic materials. The coloration of the reported X-ray- and UV-induced photochromic violegen-based materials is mainly caused by the electron transfer from donor O atom to pyridinium N atom, which is confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Figure S9). The X-ray-induced photochromic materials require a much higher threshold energy than UV-induced materials, which means that the electron-transfer pathway of X-ray-induced materials is longer than that of UV-induced materials. As reported, JU99, NTHU-9-MV, and blm-Co are all sensitive to X-rays, in which the shortest O⋅⋅⋅N distances between the electron-rich O atom and the electron-deficient N atom are 4.52, 4.83, and 4.29 Å, while in UV-induced compounds the distances are much shorter (such as JU98:3.45 Å, etc.). In 1, the shortest O⋅⋅⋅N distance between O4 and N1 atoms is 3.276 Å, and the distance of the offset π⋅⋅⋅π stacking between the pryridine ring and the benzene ring is 3.727 Å (Figure S10). These values favor the requirements for charge transfer under UV light. The dihedral angle between two pyridyl groups of the bipyridinium is 0°, which is favorable for stabilizing the charge delocalization degree and the free radicals. To be noted, compound 1 can be sensitive to not only UV light but also to soft X-ray, which might be due to that there are some longer O⋅⋅⋅N distances of 4.514, 4.582, 4.618, and 4.664 Å, quite close to the corresponding value (4.285 Å) of the reported X-ray- and UV-light-induced chromic compound [Zn2LBr4] (L = N,N'-dipropionate-4,4'-bipyridinium). Although no unequivocal criterion for the donor-acceptor distance of photochromic compounds has been established, according to previous studies and our cases (Table S2), the multipathway for electron transfer should play a key role in these viologen-based materials, which can undergo a visible color change under light of different frequencies. The sensitive detection of soft X-rays has been performed in crystalline solid through a visual color change, but it is well-known that the hybrid films are more convenient and efficient in the application as X-ray detectors. Such functional film materials can be constructed by doping sample 1 into the PMMA polymer (1@PMMA). As shown in b, 1@PMMA has also shown an efficient coloration process when it is irradiated by Cu Kα radiation. With increasing X-ray irradiation time, the color of 1@PMMA has become much deeper. Thus, 1@PMMA can be very conveniently and widely used in detecting soft X-rays.

elements.content: The color change of 1 could also be monitored by the solid-state diffuse reflectance spectrum. Before UV light irradiation, 1 shows a weak absorption band centered at about 471 nm, similar to that of some viologen-based materials. Upon UV light irradiation, two new absorption bands were found to center at about 405 and 621 nm (a), and their intensities increase gradually with the duration of UV irradiation. Kinetic studies based on the absorbance at 621 nm indicate that the coloration process exhibit fist-order kinetics with two stages (Figure S11), which show resemblance to the reported viologen-based chromic compounds. At the first stage, the photoresponsive rate increases rapidly with a higher rate constant (k 1 = 1.5 × 10–2 s–1), because the surfaces of the crystals undergo the photochemical reactions at first. In the second stage, the corresponding rate increases slowly with a lower rate constant (k 2 = 6 × 10–3 s–1), which is due to that the inner parts begin to undergo the photochemical reaction in this stage. To be noted, the value of k for the photochromic reaction is about 10 times faster than that for the thermochromic reaction, implying that the UV light irradiation is more effective than heat stimuli. During the coloration process, the UV–vis spectra of 1 and 1P are obviously different, but both IR and PXRD spectra have no significant change (Figures S3 and S12), revealing no clear structural transformation or photolysis before and after irradiation. As confirmed by EPR measurements, this photoresponsive phenomenon is caused by a photoinduced charge-transfer chemical process. EPR measurement of sample 1 shows a strong single-line signal with g = 2.0071 after coloration (b), further confirming that the photoinduced chromism is more likely to arise from photostimulated reduction of bpybc ligands to generate bpybc•– radicals (Scheme S1). To understand the photoinduced electron-transfer processes, DFT calculations have been carefully performed. As shown in Figure S13, the majority of the electron distribution of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is located on the carboxy group, while that of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is mainly centered on the pyridinum cation. Such electron distributions on HOMO and LUMO indicate that the electron-rich benzene carboxylate group and electron-deficient pyridinium unit can act as the electron donor and acceptor, respectively. In other words, the chromic process of 1 should be attributed to the electron transfer from the oxygen atoms of carboxylate group to the viologen unit. After being kept in the dark at ambient temperature for 14 d or when heated at 120 °C for about 4 h, color bleaching occurs with the disappearance of the EPR signal (b), suggesting an excellent reversibility of such a chromic process.

elements.content: Generally speaking, the photogenerated radicals can be quenched by oxygen molecules, and the bleaching process can easily occur under air atmosphere, hindering the applications such as solar energy conversion, molecular photonics, and so on. To further explore the potential applications of the chromic materials and considering the good performance of PMMA film with easy preparation, low-cost, and good mechanical properties, the powder sample 1 has been doped into the polymer matrixes to construct a new PMMA-supported hybrid film material. Upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp, the hybrid film gradually turns from yellow to blue (Figure S14). Similar to 1, two new electron absorption bands around 485 and 620 nm emerge, and their intensities increase gradually upon continuous irradiation (Figure S15). To be noted, the coloration time for 1@PMMA is slightly shorter than that of 1, which should be because the PMMA matrix hinders the oxidative quenching of viologen radicals. To study the repeatability for 1@PMMA, the absorption at 620 nm was recorded after UV irradiation and heating alternately in the air. No noticeable loss of photochromic properties for 1@PMMA was observed even after more than 10 continuous cycles (Figure S16). In contrast to naked 1, better photochromic reversibility of 1@PMMA film is because the PMMA matrix prevents the removal of lattice water molecules and slows oxygen molecules to diffuse into the framework of 1. As shown in Figure S17, 1@PMMA exhibits the absence and presence of EPR radical signals at g = 1.997 before and after irradiation, further evidencing that the colored process for 1@PMMA is caused by the generation of viologen radicals upon continuous irradiation.

elements.content: In general, the viologen-based materials, relying on reversible one-electron redox cycling between the dicationic and radical cationic states, can be colored upon light irradiation, and then discolored by heating. Strikingly, compound 1 can become deeper upon heating at 100–110 °C (a), meaning that it possesses thermochromic behavior. Initially, yellow block crystals of 1 were synthesized at 90 °C. When the reaction temperature rises to 100 °C, we unexpectedly observed the coloration of the crystals, and only the internal fraction of the crystals becomes blue (Figure S18). When the reaction temperature rises to 110 °C, whole crystals become blue. Because the coloration can be faster in an oxygen-poor atmosphere, the coloration of crystals from “core” to “edge” is observed upon heating at the appropriate temperature. Such a phenomenon indicated that the viologen radical can be also generated in the mother solution, which is further confirmed by EPR spectra (Figure S19). To the best of our knowledge, such a coloration process has not yet been found in other reported thermochromic materials. The coloration process of the crystals 1 is of great interest, indicating that the viologen radicals can generate in the internal fraction of the crystals at first. This coloration is the opposite process of the discoloration for viologen-based materials reported by the Mercier group. However, when the crystals 1 are directly heated at different temperatures, the processes of color change are slightly different, which can be monitored by the UV/vis absorption spectra. If the heating temperature is below 90 °C in air, the color of sample 1 has not changed. Strikingly, when the temperature is held for 2 h in the 100–110 °C range, sample 1 directly changes to blue (1T), but does not undergo a coloration process from “core” to “edge” because the crystals are heated under oxygen-rich condition. Correspondingly, two new absorption bands centered at 405 and 621 nm were generated rapidly, and their intensities increase gradually with the duration of heating, and finally tend to saturation, which is believed to arise from the generation of the Bpybc•– radicals through thermo-induced electron transfer. The coloration of 1T can be completely bleached upon heating at 120 °C in air, accompanied by the disappearance of two main absorption bands and the EPR signals (Figures S20, S21, and b). The coloration–decoloration processes can be achieved at different heating temperatures in air, and such coloration–decoloration phenomena were also observed in the atmosphere of water steam, indicating that such behavior is really thermochromism rather than hydrochromism. Kinetic studies indicate that the solid-state thermochromic coloration of 1 at 621 nm exhibits first-order kinetics, similar to the photocoloration reaction. As shown in Figure S22, the thermochromic reaction can be separated into two stages. At the first stage, the photoresponsive rate increases slowly with a lower rate constant (k 1 = 1.55 × 10–4 s–1). In the second stage, the corresponding rate increases rapidly with a higher rate constant (k 2 = 5.88 × 10–4 s–1). The difference in the reaction rate of two stages might be due to the fact that the thermochemical reactions occur in the core of crystals at first and then in the surfaces at the second stage. Although the UV–vis spectra of 1 and 1T are obviously different during the coloration process, both IR and PXRD spectra have no significant change (Figures S3 and S12), revealing no clear structural transformation or thermolysis before and after heating. As confirmed by EPR measurements, this thermochromic reaction is due to the thermally induced electron transfer, which is rarely reported because high temperature is deemed to be favorable for the charge-recombination. No EPR signal is observed for the as-synthesized sample of 1, while after coloration a strong single-line signal with g = 2.0021 appears (b), further confirming that the thermo-induced chromism is more likely to arise from an electron-transfer process from carboxylate O atoms to bipyridinium and the formation of stable radicals.

elements.content: The electrochemical characteristics of compound 1 were probed through cyclic voltammetry tests utilizing a three-electrode system, wherein a modified glassy carbon electrode was employed as the working electrode, Pt foil as the counter electrode, and an Ag-AgCl electrode as the reference electrode. As shown in a, there are two pairs of quasi-reversible oxidation redox peaks, corresponding to the two-step one-electron transfer behavior, which indicates that the bipyridinium groups in 1 possess electrochemical activity. The first reduction potential of 1 is observed at −0.48 V, and the second reduction potential reaches −1.06 V, bearing a resemblance to the reported viologen-based framework. To verify the electrochromic and photophysical behaviors, an electrochromic device (ECD) was assembled utilizing 1 as active component and fluorine-doped tin oxide-coated glasses as the electrodes. To determine the appropriate colored potential of ECD, the voltage was applied from 0.0 to −2 V. The optimum colored potential of ECD is established as −0.6 V for the colored state. Upon application of an optimum electric potential (E = −0.6 V) to ECD, the color of the suspension-based ECD gradually changes from slightly yellow to slightly blue (b), which undergoes the reaction of one-electron transfer from bpybc to bpybc•– during the redox process (Scheme S1). The colored ECD can return to the initial color by long exposure in air, which is due to the fact that the blue-colored radical sample is oxidized by oxygen molecules through electron transfer and reverts back to the initial state. As presented in b, the adsorption spectra of ECD in colored and bleached states display quite different absorption peaks. Two characteristic absorption peaks centered in the visible region at ∼400 and ∼600 nm are found in the colored ECD, similar to what was observed in the photochromic and thermochromic state of 1. With prolongation of the applied potential of −0.6 V, the intensities of two characteristic absorption peaks have increased rapidly, arising from the produced viologen cation radicals. When the colored ECD is bleached with exposure in air within 10 min, no apparent peak is found in the absorbance spectrum (Figure S23). The absorbance at ∼600 nm of the colored state with an applied potential of −0.6 V is about 0.07 absorbance units higher than that of the bleached state, and this circular color change can be repeated for at least seven cycles (Figure S23).

elements.content: To further explore the sensing potentials of compound 1 toward various amine vapors, 10 organic amines such as dimethyamine (DEA), ethylamine (EA), propylamine (PA), butylamine (BA), benzylamine (BZA), ammonium hydroxide, aniline (AN), dibenzyamine (DBA), diisopropylamine (DiPA), and triethylamine (TEA) were then investigated. Interestingly, with exposure to various amine vapors that has seriously threatened environment safety and human health, the pressed sample 1 differs significantly in the speed and degree of color change. Yellow 1 immediately becomes pale blue once fumed with dimethylamine vapor (from 30% dimethylamine aqueous solution). The color will become more deep with increasing exposure time, and finally the color of the sample changes from pale blue to black purple after ca. 10 s (a). 1@DEA can revert to yellow when fumed with HCl vapor for about 5 min, whereas color bleaching in air at room temperature needs much longer time (∼1 h). Once fumed with ethylamine and propylamine vapor, the pressed sample 1 immediately turns to purple, which is faster than the DEA coloration. The purple samples revert to original yellow when fumed with HCl or standing in air at room temperature. Fuming with butylamine and benzylamine for ∼10 s, the color of 1 becomes brown and green, respectively. It then reverts to original yellow when fumed with HCl for ∼2 min. The sample is less sensitive to NH3 than other amines, and it begins to become pale green after NH3 fuming for 1 min, and increased exposure time will also significantly deepen the color until purple. It will undergo self-recovery to its original color at room temperature after removal from fume. Of course, HCl fume will also bleach the purple sample for 5 min. However, when fumed with aniline, dibenzylamine, diisopropylamine, and triethylamine, sample 1 shows no color change. Notably, the sample is more sensitive to most primary amines and partial secondary amines than to tertiary amines and bulkier amines. Such a selective vapochromic phenomenon can also be observed when the pressed 1 is sprayed on the filter paper or doped into the polymer matrixes to form PMMA-supported films (Figures S24–S26).

Such a selective vapochromic phenomenon can also be observed when the pressed 1 is sprayed on the filter paper or doped into the polymer matrixes to form PMMA-supported films (Figures S24-S26).

elements.content: To further study the selective vapochromic response to different amines, the color change of the sample fumed with different amines is characterized by solid-state UV–vis and EPR spectra. As shown in b, after exposure to DEA, EA, PA, BA, BZA, and NH3 vapor for awhile, the two characteristic absorption bands centered at around 400 and 600 nm can be clearly observed in the UV–vis spectra of amine@1, which shows resemblance to those found in the photoinduced reduction of viologens. Such radical generation can also be further confirmed by electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (Figure S27). With exposure to the six above amine vapors, compound 1 shows similar strong EPR signals at g = ∼2.00, providing direct evidence of the generation of radicals. After leaving amine@1 in air for several minutes, the color of the sample 1 returns to initial yellow, accompanied by the disappearance of two characteristic absorption bands and EPR signals. These results suggest that 1 has strong capabilities to detect organic amine vapors and can be used as an indicator of vapor leakage in amines production, transportation, and storage. Importantly, 1 can be returned by leaving amine@1 in air, and no observable degradation occurs even after several cycles, indicating the colorimetric reversibility of 1. Thermal and acid–base stabilities are important parameters for the sensitive materials to detect multistimuli in the natural environment. The framework of compound 1 showed quite thermal stability up to 235 °C in air confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data at different temperature and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figures S4 and S28), but also showed high chemical stability as proved by PXRD measured after treatment with pH from 2 to 12 aqueous solution for at least 4 h (Figures S29 and S30). On the basis of the above results, compound 1 is a quite stable candidate for detecting multi external stimuli.

elements.content: A novel bipyridinium-based material with a 7-fold interpenetrated 3D framework has been solvothermally synthesized and characterized. Compound 1 has the following characteristics: (i) the short distance between the electron donor and the electron acceptor causes a significant possibility in stimuli sensitivity; (ii) the multipathways for electron transfer including the offset π···π stacking between the pyridine ring and the benzene ring provide a chance for sensing to not only UV-light but also X-ray; and (iii) the planar character of two adjacent pyridine can stabilize the radicals and the delocalization degree to generate the stable chromic state. As expected, 1 shows a striking and visible response to different types of external stimuli, especially soft X-ray, UV-light, heat, electricity, and some organic amines, due to the generation of the viologen radicals via stimuli-induced electron transfer. Of particular interest is its structural stability and good reversibility to sense these external stimuli, indicating that such smart material is a good candidate in practical application. These results not only provide insights into the design and synthesis of a molecule that can be sequentially sensitive to five different stimuli, but also outline the potential applications in X-ray detector, smart windows, inkless and erasable printing, optoelectronic and photochemical devices, memory devices and molecular switches, and so on.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel bipyridinium-based material with a 7-fold interpenetrated 3D framework has been solvothermally synthesized and characterized. Compound 1 has the following characteristics: (i) the short distance between the electron donor and the electron acceptor causes a significant possibility in stimuli sensitivity; (ii) the multipathways for electron transfer including the offset π⋅⋅⋅π stacking between the pyridine ring and the benzene ring provide a chance for sensing to not only UV-light but also X-ray; and (iii) the planar character of two adjacent pyridine can stabilize the radicals and the delocalization degree to generate the stable chromic state. As expected, 1 shows a striking and visible response to different types of external stimuli, especially soft X-ray, UV-light, heat, electricity, and some organic amines, due to the generation of the viologen radicals via stimuli-induced electron transfer. Of particular interest is its structural stability and good reversibility to sense these external stimuli, indicating that such smart material is a good candidate in practical application. These results not only provide insights into the design and synthesis of a molecule that can be sequentially sensitive to five different stimuli, but also outline the potential applications in X-ray detector, smart windows, inkless and erasable printing, optoelectronic and photochemical devices, memory devices and molecular switches, and so on.

cln_elements.content: Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.149 g, 0.5 mmol), o-H2BDC (0.035 g, 0.2 mmol), and H2bpybcCl2 (0.099 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (2 mL), EtOH (2 mL), and H2O (2 mL). The pH value was adjusted to 7 with NaOH solution. The solution was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was then heated at 90 °C for 7 days and then slowly cooled to room temperature at 5 °C/min. After being filtered off and dried at room temperature, 1 was obtained as a yellow block crystal in 40% yield based on H2BpybcCl2. Anal. Calcd for C126H118N7O56Zn7 (1): C, 49.07; H, 3.86; N, 3.18. Found: C, 48.96; H, 3.83; N, 3.19. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3442 (s), 3117 (w), 2346 (w), 2031 (w), 1600 (s), 1381 (s), 1121 (s), 812 (w), 759 (m), 668 (w), 615 (m), 551 (w), 471 (w).
